definition:
A *cycle* in a graph, digraph, or multigraph, is a simple path from a
vertex to itself (i.e., a path where the first vertex is the same as the
last vertex and no edge is repeated).

For example, consider this graph: $$\xymatrix{
A \ar@{-}[r] \ar@{-}[d] & B \ar@{-}[dl] \ar@{-}[d] \\
D \ar@{-}[r] & C
}$$

$ABCDA$ and $BDAB$ are two of the cycles in this graph. $ABA$ is not a
cycle, however, since it uses the edge connecting $A$ and $B$ twice.
$ABCD$ is not a cycle because it begins on $A$ but ends on $D$.

A cycle of length $n$ is sometimes denoted $C_n$ and may be referred to
as a polygon of $n$ sides: that is, $C_3$ is a triangle, $C_4$ is a
quadrilateral, $C_5$ is a pentagon, etc.

An *even* cycle is one of even length; similarly, an *odd* cycle is one
of odd length.
